title: 115_hr2223
content: The Act titled "Community Protection and Preparedness Act of 2017" includes a section establishing a Rail Spill Preparedness Fund. The "Community Protection and Preparedness Act of 2017" establishes a Rail Spill Preparedness Fund, including a Rail Account in the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund. A fee of $1,500 is imposed annually on certain railroad tank cars transporting Class 3 flammable liquids that do not meet specified safety regulations. The Federal Regulations require a fee to be paid by individuals transporting liquids in tank cars, regardless of train composition or phase-out schedule. The fee cannot be imposed on railroad carriers transporting Class 3 flammable liquids. The Secretary will establish procedures for fee collection using government entities and may reimburse them for their services. Amounts equivalent to the fees collected will be deposited accordingly. Amounts collected as fees for transporting Class 3 flammable liquids by rail will be deposited into the Rail Account. These funds can be used by the Secretary for removal and remediation costs, as well as making grants to States and Indian tribes for emergency planning related to such incidents. The Secretary can use fees collected for transporting Class 3 flammable liquids by rail for various purposes, including developing regional hazardous material emergency response teams, training public sector employees, and implementing other safety measures determined in consultation with States and Indian tribes. The Secretary can use fees collected for transporting Class 3 flammable liquids by rail to assist States and Indian tribes in preparing for accidents. Grants under this provision must ensure that emergency responders are trained to protect people, property, and the environment from hazardous material incidents, including those involving Class 3 flammable liquids by rail. The section discusses the transportation of Class 3 flammable liquids by rail and clarifies definitions related to this. It also states that compliance and liability under Federal or State law are not affected by this section. SEC. 3. Final rule on oil spill response plans to be issued within 3 months. SEC. 4. Funding for hiring additional track safety specialists. SEC. 5. Study on track inspections and regulations adequacy. Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the Secretary of Transportation must provide an assessment to the House and Senate committees on Transportation and Infrastructure and Commerce, Science, and Transportation. This assessment will cover the adequacy of railroad track inspections, training for inspectors and personnel, compliance with Federal track safety regulations, oversight of railroads, and evaluation of leading causes of track defects on routes with passenger trains, high-hazard flammable trains, or trains carrying poisonous materials. Trains carrying hazardous materials like explosives, radioactive material, or toxic substances traverse certain routes.
